[[United States]] | latd = 42| latm = 20| lats = 8.5| latNS = N | longd = 83| longm = 3| longs = 1.5| longEW = W | iso_region = | coordinates_display= title | roof = {{convert|272|ft|abbr=on}} | top_floor = | antenna_spire = | floor_count = 19 | floor_area = | elevator_count = | references = {{skyscraperpage|2140}} | architect = [[Daniel Burnham]] | nrhp = {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = David Whitney Building | nrhp_type = cp | partof = Grand Circus Park Historic District | partof_refnum = 83000894 | designated_nrhp_type = February 28, 1983 }} }} The '''David Whitney Building''' is a historic class-A [[skyscraper]] on the northern edge of [[downtown]] [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. It is located at 1553 [[Woodward Avenue]], adjacent to [[Grand Circus Park (Detroit)|Grand Circus Park]]. The building stands on a wedge-shaped site at the junction of Park Avenue, [[Woodward Avenue]], and Washington Boulevard. Construction on the 19-floor structure began in 1914. It is currently unused and awaiting redevelopment. It is named for [[David Whitney Jr.]], a wealthy Detroiter who earned millions of dollars as a lumber baron dealing in [[Eastern White Pine|white pine]]; his father was said to be the employer of [[Paul Bunyan (lumberjack)|Paul Bunyan]]. Famed [[Chicago]]-[[architect]] [[Daniel Burnham]] designed the Whitney. Appropriately for Detroit, the exterior was originally styled with clean lines in a [[Renaissance Revival architecture|Neo-Renaissance]] style faced with [[terra cotta]] and glazed brick. The original [[facade]] was altered in 1959 when decorative cornices were replaced with a 'modern' top. The first four stories of this building contain a large retail [[Atrium (architecture)|atrium]]. It was one of Detroit's first major [[mixed-use]] projects and was a popular location for many medical offices. The [[Detroit People Mover]]'s [[Grand Circus Park (Detroit People Mover)|Grand Circus Park station]] is located at the first and second floors of this building. It stands across Woodward Avenue from the [[David Broderick Tower]]. The building is visible from the Detroit [[People mover|People Mover]], as well as [[Comerica Park]]. Together with the adjacent Broderick Tower, it forms a "gateway" of sorts to downtown Detroit when viewed from the north. The ''[[Metro Times]]'', an early [[alternative weekly]], once published from offices in the highrise. There are 19 floors housing office and retail space with a two-story mechanical penthouse at the rear of the building. In January 2011, the Detroit Downtown Development Authority approved a $1 million loan to help Whitney Partners purchase and renovate the building. Their plan includes creating a mixed-use building and restoring the decorative exterior elements that were removed in 1959 and the four-story lobby. The partnership is still finalizing plans and financing for the project.{{cite news| title=DDA approves mixed-use plan to renovate the Whitney Building| author=John Gallagher| work=Detroit Free Press| publisher=freep.com| url= http://www.freep.com/article/20110113/BUSINESS04/101130554/1322/DDA-approves-mixed-use-plan-to-renovate-Whitney-Building| date=January 13, 2011| accessdate=January 13, 2011}} ==Gallery== File:DavidWhitneyandGrandCircusPark.jpg|[[David Broderick Tower]] (left) and the David Whitney Building line [[Grand Circus Park]].
